handling_precautions: Do not plant near edible gardens
Even touching and then touching mouth can be dangerous

primary_toxins.name: Digoxin
primary_toxins.mechanism: Inhibits sodium-potassium ATPase; increases cardiac contractility, can cause fatal arrhythmias
primary_toxins.lethal_dose: 2-3 grams of dried leaf can be fatal to adults

primary_toxins.name: Digitoxin
primary_toxins.lethal_dose: Very small amounts can be lethal

symptoms_by_severity.beschreibung: Visual disturbances (yellow-green halos), confusion, cardiac arrest

fatality_note: Numerous documented fatalities. Children are at extreme risk. A single leaf can kill a child.
first_aid_immediate: Give activated charcoal if available and person is conscious
Keep patient calm and monitor heart rate
medical_treatment: ICU care, cardiac monitoring, antidote administration, electrolyte management

prognosis.status: Guarded - depends on amount and speed of treatment

long_term_effects: Survivors may have persistent cardiac problems
collection_warnings: NEVER collect for any purpose other than ornamental
Can be confused with edible plants (comfrey)
Do not compost near food gardens
storage_risks: All parts remain toxic when dried
processing_risks: No safe processing method for consumption
Pharmaceutical extraction only under strict controls

allergy_potential.status: Low (but irrelevant due to extreme toxicity)

contraindications: ALL ORAL USE - THIS PLANT IS DEADLY

clinical_case_reports.title: Accidental digitalis poisoning due to drinking herbal tea
